attributes.title: Endogenous Gender Gap in Employment: How Business Leaders Assess Responses to Sexual Harassment

q1.value: Endogenous Gender Gap in Employment: How Business Leaders Assess Responses to Sexual Harassment

q2.value: Olle Folke | Johanna Rickne | Frances Rosenbluth | Seiki Tanaka

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The main purpose of this study is to understand how sexual harassment at the workplace affects women’s career choices. The literature suggests that women generally have a higher willingness to pay for jobs with greater flexible hours and job stability. In addition to these “typical” considerations, we conjecture that a firm’s reputation around sexual harassment will also shape women’s employment choices. This project seeks to measure employees’ willingness to pay for freedom from sexual harassment and for good firm practices in dealing with sexual harassment. We compare the value that potential employees place on firms’ handling sexual harassment against other perils of the workplace. We do this by capturing and comparing trade-offs employees are willing to make against a range of desirable workplace attributes including wages and policies.

q16.value: We propose to test the following main hypotheses: H1: Women are willing to pay more for freedom from sexual harassment than for other workplace problems such as bullying and stealing credit for work. H2: Women are willing to pay more to work for an employer that is known to handle sexual harassment swiftly and well than the counterpart that is known to handle the issue ineffectively.

q17.value: To test the hypotheses, we conduct surveys in a collaboration with Yale School of Management. The Yale School of Management conducts a student and alumni survey annually with other 31 top-ranking business schools from 25 different countries (Global Network Survey: GNAM). To examine the multidimensionality of a job offer, we embed a conjoint experiment in the survey. We adopt forced-choice conjoint methods and the experiment is designed to gauge which attribute respondents are the most concerned with for the job offer. More specifically, after showing a pair of hypothetical scenarios, we ask respondents which job offer they are more likely to accept. To test H1 and H2, we use women only sample and estimate the average marginal component effect (AMCE) of a change in the above-mentioned values of the attributes on the likelihood that the woman respondent chooses the hypothetical job. To test heterogeneous treatment effects, we use a full sample and use post-treatment questions as respondent-varying variables, and report conditional marginal means.

q18.value: Philippines, China, Mexico, Germany, Brazil, United States, France, Japan, Italy, United Kingdom, Chile, Singapore, Nigeria, Turkey, India, Costa Rica, Switzerland, Spain, South Korea, Kenya, Israel, Canada, Ireland, South Africa, Ghana, Indonesia, Australia

q2.value: Ariel BenYishay | Lisa Mueller | Philip Roessler

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: This experiment is designed to evaluate the impact of a program by USAID consisting of community dialogues in Niger. The main outcome of interest is the coverage and quality of public goods that meet citizen priority needs. Other project outcomes—responsiveness of political parties and local capacity-building to promote participatory governance—will not be directly evaluated in this impact evaluation, though the interactive effects of party responsiveness and capacity-building with public goods reform implementation will be assessed. The impact evaluation will employ a randomized design that entails selecting 24 random communes out of 48 to receive the public goods reform implementation program, centered on community dialogues.

q16.value: There are three categories of hypotheses: elite behavior, government performance, and collective action. Elite Behavior: H1: Multi-stakeholder dialogues will improve coordination and strategic ties between community elites. H2: Multi-stakeholder dialogues will strengthen the representativeness of development processes. H3: Multi-stakeholder dialogues will increase the resources local and regional governments devote to local service delivery. Government Performance: H4: Multi-stakeholder dialogues will increase the perceived legitimacy of the government among citizens in the commune. H5: Multi-stakeholder dialogues will strengthen citizen perceptions that the government is responsive to their needs and demands. H6: Multi-stakeholder dialogues will increase citizen perceptions that their government is democratic. H7: Multi-stakeholder dialogues will reduce citizen perceptions that the local government is corrupt. Collective Action: H8: Multi-stakeholder dialogues will increase citizen political participation. H9: Multi-stakeholder dialogues will increase likelihood citizens sign a petition to ensure the government invests in public priorities. H10: Multi-stakeholder dialogues will increase the likelihood citizens send an SMS to commune government to insist they address citizen priorities.

q17.value: We will test these hypotheses with baseline and endline surveys of approximately 1258 households using stratified random sampling. There will also be three elite surveys per commune. The elite surveys will target the following groups: commune mayor, administrator (in health or education), and traditional religious leader.

q2.value: Saad Gulzar | Durgesh Pathak | Sarah Thompson | Aliz Toth

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

registration_responses.q2: Saad Gulzar | Durgesh Pathak | Sarah Thompson | Aliz Toth
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q2.value: Sean Webeck | Sean Nicholson-Crotty | Jill Nicholson-Crotty

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In this study, we seek to test some of the core assumptions of public managers. One of the general assumptions about public managers is that they are risk-averse. And, public management systems are often thought to provide a decision making institution which will induce public managers to avoid risk-averse decisions. Another, related assumption about public managers is that they are motivated by the public interest. That is, the decisions they make are more likely to take into account the public interest than are those who are in the private sector and those with lower levels of public service motivation. One objective of these experiments is to assess some of these assumptions surrounding public managers. We also test some of the primary assumptions under-girding public-sector performance management systems. These systems are often thought to be rationalizing institutions in that they should induce certain expected behaviors out of the individuals (e.g., bureaucrats, citizens, or politicians) who use the information they provide. Yet, despite the assumption that these institutions are inherently rationalizing, recent work shows evidence that individuals exhibit cognitive biases when using public-sector performance information. Thus, a second objective of this project is to see if managers exhibit three specific forms of bias when using performance information: equivalence framing, reference point bias (i.e., historical and social reference points), and a status quo bias.

q16.value: Risk Aversion and Status Quo Bias: SQ1 – Public-sector managers will score higher on the uncertainty avoidance battery than private-sector managers. SQ2 – Managers who score higher on an uncertainty avoidance battery will exhibit stronger status quo bias. SQ3 – Public-sector managers will exhibit stronger status quo bias than private-sector managers. Public Service Motivation and framing effects: PSM1 – Public-sector managers will score higher on a public service motivation battery than private-sector managers. PSM2 – Managers who score higher on a public service motivation battery will be more susceptible to framing effects when asked to make decisions that affect outcomes for other people. PSM3 - Public-sector managers will be more susceptible to framing effects than private sector managers when asked to make decisions that affect outcomes for other people. Numerical Equivalence Framing NE1 – Managers will respond more strongly to items that are framed negatively than to items with a positive frame. NE2 – Managers will exhibit a negativity bias NE3 – Females will react more strongly than males to negative information. Historical and Social Reference Points HS1 – Managers to respond to negative and positive information when using both historical and social reference points. HS2 – In making interpretations of performance information, managers will give more weight to social reference points than to historical reference points.

q17.value: We use survey experiments to generate the data we will use to test our hypotheses. The population of interest is (public) managers. We will use t-tests and regressions to test for differences between our control and treatment groups as well as between treatment groups. We will test the risk-aversion assumption with an uncertainty avoidance battery. We will assess public service motivation with a battery of questions accepted in the literature. We have two experiments which test for a status quo bias. And, we will use both the risk-aversion and public service motivation battery-scores to assess the results of the status quo bias experiment. We also have three experiments for framing effects and two experiments for the reference point bias.

q27.value: Researchers, Survey delivered through a third-party (Qualtrics). But, the actual implementation is embedded in a survey experiment.

attributes.title: The Causal Effects of Moving to Opportunity on Voter Registration and Turnout

q1.value: The Causal Effects of Moving to Opportunity on Voter Registration and Turnout

q2.value: Riley Carney | Ryan Enos | Tali Mendelberg

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Prior research by Gay (2012) indicates that adults who were offered housing vouchers as part of the Moving to Opportunity housing program were less likely to participate in the political process after relocation, possibly due to the loss of social ties that accompanies residential mobility. We aim to extend this research by observing long-term civic participation among MTO participants in the years that followed, in particular, the causal effect of MTO intervention on voter registration and turnout. In addition, we wish to observe long-term participation among the adult children of MTO participants. Research by Chetty et al. found that the effects of MTO on life outcomes can change overtime, and that treatment effects are stronger for children than adults. We want to explore similar patterns for effects on political behavior.

q16.value: We hypothesize that when children are assigned to a low-poverty voucher condition, their political participation will be higher later in life than those who are assigned to a no-voucher condition. Those assigned to a standard voucher condition (unrestricted) will exhibit weaker effects. We expect those assigned as adults or teens to be much less positively affected, likely exhibiting null or negative effects.

q17.value: The research team will be licensing data about the Department of Housing and Urban Development’s Moving to Opportunity (MTO) program from the National Bureau for Economics Research. The MTO data will be matched at the individual level with voter registration records.

q19.value: The sample size of the study is approximately 16,000 individual participants.

q27.value: The intervention was implemented by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

attributes.title: Intensive D.C. GOTV: Voter Mobilization prior to the 2018 Midterm Elections

q1.value: Intensive D.C. GOTV: Voter Mobilization prior to the 2018 Midterm Elections

q2.value: Melissa Michelson | Jamil Scott | Stephanie L. DeMora

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: It is often argued that low turnout in this group reflects a vicious circle: political campaigns are often unwilling to spend resources to reach out to people who are very unlikely to vote, and this inattention leaves these voters disengaged. The aim of this study is to demonstrate the extent to which intensive mobilization efforts can break this cycle by promoting substantially higher turnout. We test the effects of letter writing, door knocking, and a combination of both on voter mobilization restricted to select wards of the Washington D.C. area.

q16.value: The principal hypothesis is that those randomly targeted for intensive mobilization will vote at higher rates than their control group counterparts. We also expect that the most intense treatment will see the largest effects compared to the two less intense treatment groups. We also will follow-up on the groups that were randomized in previous elections to see if there are enduring effects. In order to assess spillover effects, we will assess the voter turnout of others living at targeted addresses relative to the control group.

q17.value: Sample Experiments are conducted in the following locations. - Washington DC: Ward 7 - Washington DC: Ward 8 After the coordinator of that site obtained a voter file, we subset the data to include only wards 7 and 8. We then randomly extracted 2000 individuals and assigned them to one of three treatment groups. Clustering by precinct at this point ensures that the canvassers in the field would have an easier time contacting individuals assigned to the treatment groups. In other words, one precinct will not appear in more than one treatment or control group. Treatment group 1 includes 655 individuals, treatment group 2 includes 647 individuals, and treatment group 3 includes 698 individuals. The slight difference in counts per group is due to clustering. The control group consists of 112,959 individuals. Intervention The outreach effort basically consists of three treatment groups: Treatment 1 is a handwritten letter/postcard that introduced the canvasser (and gave contact information) and emphasized the importance of the election. Treatment 2 is a visit to the target voter’s address, culminating in either a conversation about the importance of the election, communication with friends or relatives, or a note saying that the canvasser had visited. Treatment 3 includes both, where the individual receives both treatments 1 and 2. Data and Outcome Measures Voter turnout will be assessed by obtaining updated voter files and calculating turnout rates for the randomly assigned treatment groups. Method for Estimating Average Treatment Effects We will report 95% confidence intervals for the average treatment effect, using a margin of error equal to the estimated standard error multiplied by the appropriate critical value from the t-distribution. This estimate will be generated by regressing turnout on treatment assignment, using the covariates listed below to generate more precise estimates. To assess robustness, we will also report a simple regression result with only block and treatment indicator, omitting prior turnout statistics. We expect these results to be similar but less precisely estimated due to the exclusion of prognostic covariates. When interpreting the results, we will rely primarily on the covariate-adjusted estimates. Covariates to use in Regression Adjustment We plan to include several covariates in our estimation in order to produce a more precise estimate of the treatment effect of election festivals intensive GOTV efforts. These covariates will be age as well as lagged versions of our dependent variables. We will include as covariates: - Voter turnout in the 2016, and 2017, and 2018 (primary) elections. Heterogeneous Treatment Effects and Additional Analyses We intend to explore the possibility that intensive mobilization is more effective where the treatment is most intense—ie. letters receipts should result in the weakest effect followed by door knocking efforts. We expect the strongest effect in treatment group 3 where both initial treatment efforts are combined.

attributes.title: Overcoming the Trust Deficit: A Field Experiment on Inter-Group Contact in Iraq

q1.value: Overcoming the Trust Deficit: A Field Experiment on Inter-Group Contact in Iraq

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: How can one of the strongest predictors of economic and political development -- social trust -- be rebuilt during and after violent ethnic conflicts? To answer this question, I leverage access to 20 IDP (internally displaced persons) camps around Iraqi Kurdistan, home to minority communities displaced by ISIS' 2014 ethnic cleansing campaign. As part of this project, I test whether a simple policy-relevant intervention -- assigning Christian IDPs to a soccer team with Sunni Arabs -- can rebuild lost trust. I expect that individuals assigned to mixed soccer teams will be more likely on average than those assigned to all-Christian teams to report tolerant attitudes and exhibit trusting behaviors toward Muslims. I also expect a post-treatment increase in tolerant attitudes among Muslims assigned to Christian teammates. This project thus provides a unique opportunity to causally identify the effect of intergroup contact in conflict zones and answers a long-standing question in social science with particular salience for migration policy debates.

q16.value: I predict that Christians on mixed teams more likely than those assigned to all-Christian teams to engage in three main behaviors: (1) Attending a Ramadan break-fast (iftar) meal attended by Muslims in the league and their families. Conditional on attendance, I expect that treated Christians are more likely to bring their families to the event. (2) Volunteering to join a mixed team next season. (3) Continuing to play soccer with Muslims two months after the league ends. In terms of attitudinal outcomes, I expect that Christians assigned to mixed teams are more likely to report tolerant, anti-sectarian, and pro-democracy attitudes than those assigned to an all-Christian team. Lastly, relative to their survey responses before the tournament, I expect that Muslims assigned to mixed teams are more likely to report tolerant, anti-sectarian, and pro-democracy attitudes.

registration_responses.q1: Overcoming the Trust Deficit: A Field Experiment on Inter-Group Contact in Iraq
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This study has two goals, one experimental and one involving measurement. The former is to experimentally investigate the effects of priming geographic identity. The latter is to explore the coherence and correlates of a generalized measure of geographic identity as applied to national, state, and local identity. Previous work has invoked concepts of national identity (particularly American), regional identity (particularly with respect to the South), state identity (or the absence of it), and community identity, but little work has been done to integrate levels of geographic identity into a broader concept. This study is a first step towards linking and measuring these concepts.

q16.value: The experimental hypotheses are 1) priming geographic identity increases social trust and 2) priming geographic identity increases political trust. The first and most important measurement hypothesis is that the scale used in this study performs well as a coherent measure of national, state, and local identity. I also predict that individuals with strong geographic identity will feel more positive towards the relevant place, has lived there longer, have stronger general and scale-particular social trust, have stronger general and scale-particular political trust, be more politically and socially active, and express a desire to be more socially and politically engaged.

q17.value: Experimental hypotheses will be tested with differences in means. Measurement hypotheses will be tested with differences of means and regressions. The coding of variables, question wording, and more specific descriptions of analyses can be found in the analysis plan attached.

registration_responses.q16: The experimental hypotheses are 1) priming geographic identity increases social trust and 2) priming geographic identity increases political trust. The first and most important measurement hypothesis is that the scale used in this study performs well as a coherent measure of national, state, and local identity. I also predict that individuals with strong geographic identity will feel more positive towards the relevant place, has lived there longer, have stronger general and scale-particular social trust, have stronger general and scale-particular political trust, be more politically and socially active, and express a desire to be more socially and politically engaged.
registration_responses.q17: Experimental hypotheses will be tested with differences in means. Measurement hypotheses will be tested with differences of means and regressions. The coding of variables, question wording, and more specific descriptions of analyses can be found in the analysis plan attached.

attributes.title: Talking about addiction: do stigmatized labels affect perceptions of substance use and drug policy?

q1.value: Talking about addiction: do stigmatized labels affect perceptions of substance use and drug policy?

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Does the way we talk about people who use drugs affect levels of stigma? Do media portrayals of people who use drugs affect people’s policy preferences? The opioid crisis killed a record 72,000 people in 2017, highlighting the need for effective medical and policy solutions. Stigma toward people who use drugs can cause social isolation, discourage treatment seeking, and cause some clinicians to resist delivering treatment. More broadly, stigma may affect policy preferences among legislators and their constituents and thus play a role in shaping drug policy. Doctors have advocated reducing stigma by replacing the pejorative word “addict” with the more neutral “person with substance use disorder,” but little is known about the effectiveness of this approach on reducing stigma. I will therefore conduct two experiments to test the effect of labels used to describe people who use drugs. The first experiment will use a conjoint design to directly measure stigma toward people who use drugs. The second experiment will test the effect of labels for people who use drugs on respondents’ opinions about drug policy. This study makes several contributions. First, I provide the most rigorous examination to date of the effect of “addict” and “substance use disorder” labels on stigma. Second, I investigate the potential connection between stigma and policy beliefs, a connection that has been neglected in public health and political science literature. Third, I consider stigma as a framing device, a theoretical innovation that can deepen our understanding of stigma and its potential effects. Finally, I attempt to measure how blame and dehumanization mediate the relationship between stigmatizing labels and people’s policy preferences.

q16.value: Study 1: H1: Respondents will prefer to hire people with a substance use disorder over addicts and alcoholics. They will prefer a neutral baseline over all substance-use conditions. Study 2: H2: Compared to the label “addict,” the presence of the label "substance use disorder" in an article about opioid use will increase support for general funding to combat the opioid crisis and increase support for treatment-oriented policies, while reducing support for punitive policies. H3: The effect of the labels on punitive policy preferences will be heightened for Republicans versus Democrats.. H4: The effect of the labels on policy preferences will be mediated by levels of blame and dehumanization toward people who use drugs. The addict treatment will produce higher levels of blame and dehumanization than the SUD treatment and the pure control. I will additionally plan to explore the following research questions, which raise important issues for which I do not have strong theoretical expectations: Study 1: RQ1: How do negative preferences for people who use drugs compare to negative preferences for other stigmatized groups?

q17.value: Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants Participants will be United States residents age 18 and over recruited on the Amazon Mechanical Turk online marketplace. All Turkers are eligible to participate in this study who meet the specified qualifications and did not take part in an earlier pilot study. The sample size will be approximately 1000 for Experiment 1 and 2500 for Experiment 2 – data collection will continue until all funds allocated to the project are exhausted. Researchers have no role in selecting the participants after listing the project on Mechanical Turk. Randomization approach Experiment 1: I will use a conjoint design in which respondents evaluate eight pairs of job candidate profiles. Respondents will first be presented with the prompt: “Imagine that you need to hire a candidate as your coworker at a past, present, or future job. You have full transparency on the candidates' backgrounds. On the following screens, you will be shown 2 job candidates that have applied to the position. For each pair of candidates, please indicate which candidate you think should be given priority in hiring. Even if you are not entirely sure, please indicate which of the two you would be most likely to choose.” They will then be shown eight pairs of job candidate profiles side-by-side. The profiles will be randomly generated by the Qualtrics online survey platform with the following levels and attributes: -Recommendation quality [Poor, Fair, Good, Very good, excellent] -Cover letter quality [Poor, Fair, Good, Very good, excellent] -Current job [Unemployed, Consultant, Salesperson, Office clerk, Project manager] -Years experience [
